issue.title: Don't look for NilClassPolicy

repository.name: pundit
repository.description: Minimal authorization through OO design and pure Ruby classes

issue.body:
Hello, small fix, that @jnicklas talked about

Fixes #251

body:
I'm actually dead against this change. To me it goes against the philosophy that Pundit is just a handful of helpers and an unopinionated style of doing things.

By example, in view logic, rather than having a nice, encapsulated

``` ruby
class NilClassPolicy < ApplicationPolicy

  # Nobody can see nothing.
  def show?
    false
  end

end
```

which allows me to write in a view

``` ruby
policy(object_which_might_be_nil).show?
```

I now have the inconvenience of having to check

``` ruby
object_which_might_be_nil && policy(object_which_might_be_nil).show?
```

and I have to do that _everywhere_ I want to use `show?`, `edit?`, etc. with an object that could be nil.

I now can't use the [null object pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_Object_pattern) with Pundit.
@bendilley that's actually a pretty good point.

> I can't imagine any situation where someone would actually want to implement NilClassPolicy.

and https://github.com/elabs/pundit#just-plain-old-ruby seem at odds with each other. If the ethos is “you can do whatever you want with it, it's flexible!” then perhaps this feature should be an addition to the `README` on how to configure your own policies to disallow `nil`, rather than forcing the gem as a whole to ignore it.
I also miss being able to use the null object pattern with Pundit and would petition to have this change reversed.
I would also like to see this change reversed.

issue.title: Allow specification of a NilClassPolicy

repository.name: pundit
repository.description: Minimal authorization through OO design and pure Ruby classes

issue.body:
This saves having to check whether objects are nil before checking their
policy.

This contradicts the intent of elabs/pundit#251 and could represent a
breaking change for some.

@jnicklas I hope you'll consider my reasoning here - I am using this branch in a project for checking permissions on associations which can legitimately be nil.
